Inference: Soil moisture declines during high temperature and weather-based irrigation increases indicate strong evaporative loss overpowering irrigation
Description: Even when weather logic boosts irrigation, high heat accelerates evaporation faster than irrigation can replenish moisture.
short rationale: Shows heat-driven losses even with higher irrigation; moderate operational sensitivity.

Inference: Soil moisture increases during cool, humid periods despite weather-based irrigation reductions indicate rainfall or natural moisture retention
Description: Reduced irrigation combined with environmental moisture causes soil moisture to rise naturally.
short rationale: Natural moisture effect; very low sensitivity.

Inference: Weather-based irrigation increases during low humidity accompanied by rising soil moisture indicate effective compensation for atmospheric dryness
Description: The system properly detects dry air and increases irrigation enough to improve soil conditions.
short rationale: Shows effective dryness compensation; low privacy risk.

Inference: Weather-based irrigation reductions during high humidity paired with stable soil moisture indicate naturally low evaporative demand
Description: Humidity reduces drying, so cutting irrigation does not reduce soil moisture.
short rationale: Humidity-driven stability; very low sensitivity.

Inference: Weather-based increases during rising temperature with falling soil moisture indicate climate-driven dryness.
Description: As temperature climbs and moisture drops, the system increases irrigation appropriately.
short rationale: Heat response insight; low sensitivity.

Inference: Weather-based reductions during falling temperatures with rising soil moisture reflect wet-season transitions
Description: Cooler air and natural moisture support irrigation cutbacks without harming soil moisture.
short rationale: Wet-season adjustment; minimal privacy impact.

Inference: Stable soil moisture during fluctuating temperature and humidity and variable weather adjustments indicates buffered soil conditions
Description: Soil retains water well and is less sensitive to environmental and irrigation variations.
short rationale: Buffered soil insight; very low sensitivity.

Inference: Soil moisture dropping despite cool temperatures and weather-driven irrigation increases indicates extremely dry soil or poor infiltration
Description: Even under favorable temperatures, irrigation cannot increase soil moisture.
short rationale: Reveals severe dryness/infiltration issues; moderate sensitivity.

Inference: Soil moisture rising during high temperature and high humidity despite weather reductions suggests heavy rainfall or strong dew formation
Description: Moisture gain under otherwise drying conditions implies significant natural water input.
short rationale: Indicates natural input overriding controls; low sensitivity.

Inference: Sharp rises in soil moisture during weather-based irrigation increases that occur at night during low temperatures indicate optimal watering timing
Description: Cool nighttime conditions maximize irrigation efficiency, leading to improved moisture outcomes.
short rationale: Optimal timing insight; very low sensitivity.

Inference: Weather-based increases that occur during peak afternoon temperatures but soil moisture fails to rise indicate evaporative loss exceeding irrigation rate
Description: Heat nullifies irrigation impact during the hottest parts of the day.
short rationale: Heat nullifies irrigation; low sensitivity.

Inference: Weather-based reductions during humidity spikes that do not change soil moisture indicate minor rainfall or mist
Description: Rain or atmospheric moisture increases humidity without significantly affecting soil water levels.
short rationale: Minor atmospheric moisture effect; very low sensitivity.

Inference: Large soil moisture increases during cool, humid mornings following weather-driven reductions indicate dew-driven soil hydration
Description: Dew formation adds moisture even though the system reduced irrigation.
short rationale: Dew-driven gain; very low sensitivity.

Inference: Soil moisture decline during high humidity and stable temperature despite weather-driven irrigation increases indicates deep soil dryness
Description: Surface conditions appear moist, but deeper soil layers demand large amounts of water.
short rationale: Highlights deep dryness requiring heavy irrigation.

Inference: Soil moisture stability during high temperature and weather-based irrigation increases suggests fixed-rate irrigation insufficient to offset heat
Description: Watering boosts are not strong enough to overcome evaporative losses.
short rationale: Shows irrigation insufficient under heat; low privacy risk.

Inference: Weather-based irrigation reductions during falling humidity and stable soil moisture indicate predictive rainfall-based logic failing to match reality
Description: The system expects rain but moisture does not improve.
short rationale: Indicates forecast mismatch; modest operational detail.

Inference: Weather-based irrigation increases during rising humidity and increasing soil moisture indicate conflicting environmental signals
Description: Humidity suggests moist air while irrigation boosts suggest perceived dryness from forecasts.
short rationale: Conflicting signals; low sensitivity.

Inference: Temperature spikes followed by soil moisture drops and weather-driven increases signal diurnal dryness cycles
Description: Daily heat waves push the system to compensate for predictable moisture loss.
short rationale: Diurnal dryness response; low privacy impact.

Inference: Temperature drops with soil moisture rise during weather-based reductions indicate real-time rain absorption
Description: Cooling from rainfall aligns with increasing moisture and reduced irrigation.
short rationale: Rain absorption pattern; very low sensitivity.

Inference: Soil moisture decline despite cool temperatures and high humidity with weather-based irrigation increases indicates high wind-driven evapotranspiration
Description: Wind can cause drying even under otherwise moist and cool atmospheric conditions.
short rationale: Wind-driven drying despite irrigation; moderate sensitivity.

Inference: Soil moisture plateauing under fluctuating humidity and weather-based increases indicates soil saturation limit
Description: Irrigation boosts do not raise moisture further because soil capacity is reached.
short rationale: Saturation limit; low privacy risk.

Inference: Soil moisture fall under rising humidity and weather-based reductions suggests local humidity not tied to soil hydration
Description: Humidity increases may represent atmospheric changes unrelated to soil moisture needs.
short rationale: Humidity unrelated to soil need; low sensitivity.

Inference: Weather-based reductions coupled with rapid soil moisture rise during cold fronts reflect accurate rainfall anticipation
Description: The system reduces irrigation just as rainfall or cold-induced dew increases moisture.
short rationale: Accurate anticipation; very low sensitivity.

Inference: Weather-based increases with soil moisture drop and sudden humidity fall strongly indicate incoming dry air mass
Description: The system detects dryness and soil moisture confirms environmental drying.
short rationale: Dry air detection; modest operational detail.

Inference: Weather-based reductions during simultaneous soil moisture rise and temperature fall indicate rain-triggered cooling and hydration
Description: Rain cools the environment and increases moisture, prompting irrigation suppression.
short rationale: Rain-triggered adjustment; very low sensitivity.

Inference: Weather-based increases with stable temperatures but falling humidity and soil moisture indicate humidity-dominant irrigation logic
Description: Dry air drives irrigation behavior more than temperature conditions.
short rationale: Humidity-weighted control; low privacy risk.

Inference: Increasing soil moisture at night without weather-based irrigation increases but with high humidity suggests dew-based soil recharge
Description: Moisture rises purely due to condensation under humid night conditions.
short rationale: Dew recharge insight; very low sensitivity.

Inference: Decreasing soil moisture despite weather-based reductions and cool temperatures signals prolonged drought conditions
Description: Even reduced irrigation and favorable temperatures cannot maintain moisture.
short rationale: Indicates ongoing drought; moderate operational sensitivity.

Inference: Weather-based increases showing strong correlation with temperature spikes but weak correlation with humidity changes indicate temperature-weighted decision-making
Description: The system reacts more strongly to heat than atmospheric moisture.
short rationale: Temperature-weighted logic; modest exposure.

Inference: Weather-based reductions occurring consistently during rapid humidity rises and matched by soil moisture increases indicate good rainfall detection alignment
Description: Irrigation pauses because humidity signals incoming rain and soil moisture confirms it.
short rationale: Good alignment; very low sensitivity.
